numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The legacy boost is not equal across income status.
2. The legacy boost for the 70th percentile is higher than the legacy boost for the 10th percentile.
3. The legacy boost for the 70th percentile is lower than the legacy boost for the 99th percentile.
4. Some applicants are in the top 10% of wealth.
5. If an applicant is in the top 10% of wealth and is a legacy, then the chance of acceptance increases strongly.
6. Some applicants are not legacy.
7. Some applicants are in the bottom 70% to 80% of wealth.
8. The chance of acceptance for a top-10%-wealth legacy applicant is much higher than the chance of acceptance for a non-legacy applicant in the bottom 70% to 80% of wealth.
9. I wonder what test the study used.
10. I wonder what the test scores were.
11. I wonder why the study chose only these schools.
12. Some schools removed their legacy policy late in the studied date range.
13. If some schools removed their legacy policy late in the studied date range, then the data may be skewed.
14. Test scores are not the only factor that influences admission.
15. Other variables may influence admission.
16. An essay may influence admission.
17. A resume may influence admission.
18. I am a senior.
19. I apply to college.
20. Some colleges are elite colleges.
21. For elite colleges, I often compete with applicants who have legacy.
22. Legacy applicants have a higher chance of acceptance than non-legacy applicants.
23. If I compete with legacy applicants, then it is harder for me to get into the colleges that I want.
24. If legacy applicants have a higher chance of acceptance, then my chance of acceptance is lower.
25. The headline is: Elitism of Elite Schools.
26. The headline is: Daddy's Money gets you in the Ivy League.
